title: How to Scan a Document Wirelessly to Your Computer with an HP Deskjet 5525

steps.title: Turn on your printer.
steps.content: Turn on your printer. Make sure it is plugged into a power source and press the power button to turn it on.

steps.title: Make sure your printer’s connected to the same Wi-Fi network as your computer.
steps.content: Make sure your printer’s connected to the same Wi-Fi network as your computer. You'll need to access the control panel, Wireless Wizard set up, then follow the instructions to connect.

steps.title: Open the printer’s flatbed scanner.
steps.content: Open the printer’s flatbed scanner. Merely lift it up away from the printer.

steps.title: Add your document.
steps.content: Add your document. Lay, facing down, the document or photo you will be scanning.

steps.title: Turn on your computer.
steps.content: Turn on your computer. Make sure you’re connected to the same Wi-Fi network as your printer.

steps.title: Open the HP Deskjet application.
steps.content: Open the HP Deskjet application. From your computer desktop, click on the Start menu then Programs. Look for the HP Deskjet 5520 series program or HP Scan link. The program will load and then detect the connected printer in your network.

steps.title: Select a shortcut.
steps.content: Select a shortcut. From the left panel, you can see a list of available scan settings for the most common scanning tasks or types.

steps.title: Adjust settings.
steps.content: Adjust settings. On the right panel, after you’ve chosen a scan shortcut, you can further adjust your settings: Select scan size —Define how large the scanned document or photo is. You can choose from the Entire Scan Area, a Letter, an A4, and other various dimensions. Select output type —Define the output file’s color. It can be set to Color, Grayscale, or Black & White. Select resolution —Define the output file’s resolution in dots per inch (dpi). Select item type —Define whether your output is a Document or a Photo. Select file type —Define the file type of your output file. It can be in Bitmap, JPEG, PNG, TIFF, or PDF formats.

steps.title: Preview your image.
steps.content: Preview your image. Tick on Show Scan Preview. It is a good idea to review what the output will be like before confirming the scanning process.

steps.title: Further customize your settings.
steps.content: Further customize your settings. If you want to further tweak your settings, you can do so by clicking on the Advanced Settings link toward the bottom of the box. Scan — A dialog box will appear to show you the progress while scanning. Lighten or Darken —You can further adjust the output’s Brightness and Contrast in the Preview screen. Just drag the corresponding bars until you find your proper setting. Rotate —You can either rotate 90 degrees to the right or to the left by clicking on the corresponding buttons. Crop —You can do some final cropping and selections before finally scanning the photo or document.

steps.title: Save your image.
steps.content: Save your image. Click on Save to define your output file’s name and location on your computer.
